Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Aquisition of a 500 MHz NMR Spectrometer
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) and support from the Chemistry Research Instrumentation and Facilities (CRIF) Programs Professor John Sheridan from Rutgers Universvity Newark and colleagues Frank Jordan, Elena Galoppini, Frieder Jaekle and Darren Hansen will aquire a 500 MHz NMR spectrometer. The proposal is aimed at enhancing research training and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) development of functional conjugated macrocycles and polymers for optoelectronic applications and synthesis of chiral Lewis pairs for small molecule activation; (b) investigation of stimuli-responsive metal-containing polymers; (c) synthesis of functional molecules for dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs), host-guest complexes, and biosensors; (d) development of sustainable polymers from renewable resources; (e) investigation of thiamin diphosphate (ThDP)-dependent enzymes as well as synthesis of labeled coenzymes, substrate analogues and inhibitors; and (f) mechanistic studies on quinolone quorum sensing.


Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the elucidation of the structure of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the dynamics of interactions between molecules in solution. Access to state-of-the-art NMR spectrometers is essential to chemists who are carrying out frontier research. The results from these NMR studies will have an impact in synthetic organic/inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry and biochemistry. Many research projects associated with this application will have a direct impact on society, as they aim to develop polymers fo optoelectronics, metal containing polymers, materials for solar cells, and investigations of enzyme inhibitors and bio-sensing. This instrument will be an integral part of teaching as well as research at Rutgers University Newark.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant enabled the purchase of a 500 MHz multinuclear Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectrometer from Bruker Biospin. Seventy percent of the cost was provided by the grant, 30% from Rutgers University. NMR spectroscopy is an absolutely vital technique for the characterization of chemical species and this new instrument is the workhorse machine for the Department of Chemistry at Rutgers University in Newark as well as a number of external users in the northern New Jersey region. The new spectrometer replaced an aging (18 years) unit that was inefficient and past its useful lifetime. It has ‘state of the art’ capabilities, including advanced automation that allows many more samples to be analyzed. The machine currently has 48 trained users from 12 research groups at Rutgers, NJIT and Rutgers Biomedical and Health Sciences in Newark, NJ. The machine is part of the Rutgers University – Newark, NMR facility and is overseen by a full-time Ph.D. level facility manager. The machine is used primarily for research, however it is also used for teaching undergraduate students in organic chemistry laboratory and other upper level lab courses. Approx. 250 undergraduates enroll in these courses each year and use data collected on the machine: some are also trained to collect their own data. The instrument was installed in mid 2014 and to date 10 peer-reviewed publications have been published in leading journals acknowledging the support from NSF. It is anticipated that up to 50 publications per year will result from research that utilizes this instrument.

The broader impact activities involved:-

(i)              The acquisition of a new 500 MHz NMR spectrometer will allow the continued generation of new fundamental knowledge in the general areas of materials and polymer chemistry, organic, organometallic and inorganic synthetic chemistry, biochemistry.  

(ii)            The purchase of this instrument facilitates the training of a diverse group of graduate, undergraduate and high school students. Rutgers University in Newark is the most diverse university in the U.S. as reported by U.S. News and World Report for the past 18 years and more than half of the undergraduate chemistry majors are women. This instrument provides access for this under-represented group to the most modern instrumentation and scientific techniques.
